 1. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. OVERVIEW 1.1 The consumptions of energy and electricity in Thailand have grown at high rates over the past decade and particularly since 1986 due to the strong economic performance of the country, arising from rapid industrial growth, and increases in exports, foreign investment and tourism. In spite of this rapid growth, however, the energy situation in Thailand remains characterized by relatively modest commercial energy consumption in relation to the country's development (320 kilograms of oil equivalent (koe) of energy consumption per capita compared with an average of 420 koe per capita for all of Asia). This includes a relatively high share (35%) of traditional fuels in the final energy consumption. The outlook is for rapid growth in commercial energy consumption as the economy continues expanding. The primary commercial energy supply is projected to grow rapidly at an average annual rate of about 8.0% over the next five years (1996- 2000) and then at about 5.7% for the next decade. 1.2 While much of the energy growth in the early 1980s was met by imports, efforts in the 1980s to promote the development of indigenous energy resources had a visible impact on the pattern of commercial energy consumption: the share of oil fell from about 90% of total primary commercial energy in 1980 to about 70% in 1990. During that period, the shares of indigenous lignite and natural gas grew steadily, reaching 10% and 16%, respectively, by 1990. Due to the Government's continuing efforts, the share of imported oil is anticipated to fall further to about 60% by the year 2005; it is, however, unlikely to decline below that level. A major increase in the consumption of imported coal (mostly for power generation) is projected in the late 1990s, and coal is expected to attain a share of 8% of primary energy consumption after the year 2001. 1.3 The sectoral composition of energy demand has been marked by a progressive increase in the share of the transport sector, which grew 11% p.a. through the 1980s and by 1990 accounted for 70% of petroleum products consumption. Electricity consumption has increased faster than energy consumption as a whole, averaging 14% p.a. in the last three years. As a result, the share of electricity in final commercial energy consumption grew from 11% to 15% in the 1980s, with a similar increase in the share of electricity in primary energy use from 7% to 11 %. B. ENERGY SECTOR INSTITUTIONS 1.4 The energy sector in Thailand is operated by a number of well-managed and mature public institutions. There are numerous energy-related agencies, spreading across many ministries and include several cabinet level committees. Energy policy and planning is vested in key governmental organizations. At the highest level is the National Energy Policy Council (NEPC) which is chaired by the Prime Minister. The National Energy Policy Office (NEPO), the secretariat to NEPC, acts as its operating arm, and
 2 functions primarily as a link between NEPC and the country's energy state enterprises and conducts all energy policy work. NEPO is the de facto regulator of the energy sector. Other departments involved in energy affairs are: (a) the Department of Mineral Resources, responsible for assessing and preliminary exploration of the country's coal and petroleum reserves; (b) the Department of Energy Development and Promotion, which conducts research and development and monitors energy sector activities; and (c) the Department of Industrial Works, responsible for controlling industrial air and water pollution. 1.5 Energy state enterprises enjoy a large degree of autonomy in the conduct of day- to-day operations; however, they are subject to strict government control in all matters relating to investment planning and financing. Because of strict procedures for controlling public debt, all loans made by energy state enterprises requiring government guarantees must be approved by the Fiscal Policy Office of the Ministry of Finance and finally approved by the Cabinet, and subsequently endorsed by the National Debt Policy Committee. 1.6 The Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) -- the dominant entity in the petroleum sector -- is involved in downstream oil and gas activities; upstream activities are carried out by the private sector. PTT is responsible, inter alia, for the purchase, transport, processing and sale of natural gas. However, PTT competes with international oil companies and has a third of the market share in the distribution and marketing of oil. 1.7 The power sector is primarily organized around three wholly-owned state enterprises. The Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) is the major producer of electricity and is also responsible for developing and dispatching the bulk- power high voltage transmission system. EGAT has the authority to purchase electricity from cogenerators or other private sources for distribution over the grid. The Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA) and the Provincial Electricity Authority (PEA) own the distribution systems and some subtransmission facilities. MEA and PEA distribute electricity purchased from EGAT to the Bangkok metropolitan area and the rest of the country, respectively. Highlights of their respective operation are provided in Annex 1. C. THE POWER SECTOR Electricity Demand 1.8 The power sector in Thailand has grown at a rapid pace over the past two decades. The electricity market growth is among the highest in the world and has been fueled by the country's high economic growth rate. Considerable progress has been made in making electricity widely available, especially in provincial urban areas. Industrial consumption has also been growing rapidly.

PEA's Investment Program 1.15 While the service areas of MEA are completely electrified, PEA is still in the process of completing the electrification of the more remote areas of the country. To date, PEA has electrified 98% of the villages in its service area. And, although PEA sales only slightly exceed MEA's, it serves the preponderance of the country's population. At the end of FY1995, PEA had more than 9 million customers compared with about 1.8 million for MEA. Currently, there is a wide disparity in electricity usage between the two distribution utilities due, in part, to the intense industrial and commercial development of Bangkok, and in part to the lower incomes and more recent development of the outlying areas. But, this situation is changing.

SECTOR STRATEGY AND ISSUES 1.18 To meet the rapidly increasing demand for energy and to create an industry structure that is both efficient and responsive to commercial incentives, the Government's energy strategy calls for the following: (a) A phased privatization and restructuring program covering the principal power sector entities, EGAT, PEA, and MEA. The Government has already created a publicly-listed generation subsidiary of EGAT in EGCO. A first step has been the categorization of these entities as Excellent State Enterprises -- which accords them less government control in their operations and increased flexibility in financial management and in establishing staffing and compensation structures. The privatization/ restructuring program for PEA and MEA is being defined and implementation is underway. The current focus calls for increased management and operational reorganization ( paras. 2.6 to 2.8). (b) A substantially increased program of investments in the power sector. The Government envisages investments of over US$10 billion equivalent by EGAT, close to US$5 equivalent billion by PEA and US$5 billion equivalent by MEA during the Eighth Plan (1997-2001). (c) Involvement of the private sector in funding part of the large power sector investments. This stems from the Government's concern about the magnitude of power sector investments and the broader implications of incurring additional public debt for the purpose. A first tangible step has been the public-listing of EGCO (a generation entity affiliated to EGAT). A comprehensive private power solicitation program is underway for 3,800 MW of generation (para. 1.23). (d) A credible and transparent scheme for power sector regulation. The existing scheme of regulation has been working satisfactorily, as evidenced by operating efficiency and the lack of power shortages. However, the need for orienting the regulatory framework to a more commercial sector structure which has private investment has been recognized (paras. 3.6 and 3.7). Under the proposed project, the Government will undertake a comprehensive study to define the structure of the future regulatory system, including functions and procedures. (The Terms of Reference for this work are at Annex 5). (e) A thrust towards energy conservation, both through economically efficient pricing of resources and through other government directives. Concerned with the rapid growth in energy consumption and its impact on the economy and the environment, the Government is making serious efforts
 7 towards fostering energy conservation in all sectors of the economy. Some of the initiatives are described in para. 1.19. (f) A stimulation of industrial growth outside of Bangkok, with development of infrastructure and granting of tax incentives to promote such growth. This would create growth centers in the provincial areas relieving the infrastructural strain from Bangkok. (g) Improvement of the efficiency of the distribution system and upgrading and automating the system to operate at the higher levels of reliability necessary for industry. E. DEMAND SIDE MANAGEMENT (DSM) AND ELECTRICITY CONSERVATION 1.19 While pursuing a large power development program, the Government has planned a thrust towards energy conservation. Its DSM program, supported by the Global Environmental Facility (GEF) under the Distribution System and Energy Efficiency Project (Loan 3598-TH), has a four-pronged approach: (a) provision of user and manufacturer incentives and consumer education to direct practices and attitudes toward energy efficient technologies; (b) development of efficiency standards and testing capabilities to exercise control and monitor efficiency improvements; (c) development and promulgation of building and appliance codes to allow for the enforcement of minimum standards; and (d) continued pursuit of technological improvements and adaptation to Thai conditions. The project is progressing very well and the current demand savings target of about 1,100 MW over the next five years, substantially exceeds the original target of about 300 MW. F. ENVIRONMENT 1.20 In the last few years, the Government has placed a strong emphasis on environmentally sound and sustainable development. Its 1992 Energy Conservation Promotion Act, created an Energy Conservation Fund, financed by surcharges on petroleum products and electricity. The Act provides for a rigorous enforcement of energy conservation in factories and buildings. The Environmental Quality Act of 1992: (a) substantially reorganized the environmental bureaucracy making it more responsive to environmental protection; (b) established a Central Environmental Fund for concessional financing of environmental projects by the private and public sectors; and (c) recognized for the first time the importance of involving Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) in development. Gaining from its experience under the Third Power System Development Project (Loan 3423-TH), the Government has increasingly emphasized involvement of affected people and selected NGOs in environmentally sensitive projects and formalized this in the evaluation of Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs).

PRIVATE SECTOR PARTICIPATION AND REFORM IN THE POWER SECTOR 1.21 Power sector reform in Thailand began in 1992 with the issuance of the seventh National Economic and Social Development Plan (NESDP). This Plan which covers the period 1992-1996, led to the development of a Cabinet resolution for power sector reform providing indicative targets for restructuring, corporatization and privatization in the power sector. The main objectives of this resolution are to: (a) encourage the operation of power utilities as commercial organizations with increased efficiency and flexibility; (b) reduce the investment and debt burden of the Government; (c) promote private sector participation in the power sector through IPPs and asset divestiture; and (d) utilize energy resources efficiently. Progress towards achieving all these objectives over the last three years has been substantive. Despite the slippage of some targets in a few instances, many of the reform goals specified in the Plan have been achieved or are in advanced stages of implementation. Commitment to continued reform is also clearly in evidence. 1.22 The Bank's operational involvement in the Thai power sector has facilitated continuing inputs to the power sector privatization and reform process. The actions undertaken are broadly in-line with recommendations in the Bank's study entitled "State Enterprise: Improvement, Privatization and Private Sector Participation" (Report No. 1312-TH). These recommendations include: (a) EGCO to be fully divested and its management made independent of EGAT; (b) the pace of introducing IPPs to be accelerated; (c) EGAT to be divested into a number of generation companies, with EGAT becoming a transmission and power pool company; (d) distribution companies and large industrial consumers to be allowed to purchase directly from any power producer; and (c) an independent regulatory agency to be set up when the Government's holdings of EGAT, MEA and PEA shares are diluted. In regard to PEA, the study recommends: (a) removal of subsidies between regions; (b) decentralization of management; and (c) fostering competition through split up of the entity and monitoring and comparing performance of the individual units. 1.23 The reform and privatization actions discussed below indicate both the success of the Thai power privatization and reform effort in meeting stated objectives and its conformance with World Bank recommendations for the sector. Private Sector Participation (a) Asset Divestiture. During 1992, EGAT established EGCO as its subsidiary company with an issued share capital of Baht 100 million divided into 10 million shares of Baht 10 each. On September 30, 1993, EGAT held the entire equity with the exception of 15 shares which were issued to EGAT senior management to comply with SET regulations. In 1994, a further 186 million shares of Baht 10 each were issued, all of which are held by EGAT except for one million held by the Crown Property Bureau and which increased EGAT's total holding to almost 192 million shares. In addition to the flotation of additional shares by EGCO during the year, it also set up its own subsidiary, the Rayong Electricity
 9 Generating Company (REGCO). In November 1994, a public offering of 204 million shares in EGCO raised Baht 4.5 billion. Presently, 50% of EGCO is publicly listed, EGAT holds 48% of the equity and the Thai Property Crown Bureau the remaining 2%. EGAT will further reduce its equity holding in EGCO to below 40% by end-1996 by incorporating the Khanom Thermal Station under EGCO. (b) Small Power Producers (SPPs) and Co-Generation. The first step taken by the Government towards increasing private sector participation was allowing co- generators and SPPs to sell power to EGAT. In 1994, a Co-generation Agreement was signed with a private company to bring on line a new 60 MW facility. Currently, there are 20 SPPs with a total installed capacity of 669 MW mostly utilizing traditional fuels such as bagasse, rice husk, wood, etc. (c) Independent Power Producers (IPPsa. To meet the ever increasing power requirements, Thailand launched what could be the world's largest competitive IPP solicitation program. EGAT announced the first request for proposals on December 15, 1994 to purchase 3,800 MW from IPPs in two stages. Stage I, for 1,000 MW during the years 1998-2000, and Stage 2, for 2,800 MW in the years 2001 and 2002. As of December 1995, 104 registered IPPs/bidders have formed into 32 consortiums and have submitted 50 IPP proposals totalling 39,067 MW. The evaluation of IPP proposals has been completed. Enterprise Commercialization/Corporatization (a) The two distribution entities, PEA and MEA, have both prepared corporatization/privatization action plans. The PEA action plan has been approved by the Cabinet. It is now in the phase of defining detailed implementation plans to manage the transition from the existing organizational structure to the future commercial organizations. PEA will be transformed over a 4-5 year period from a centrally controlled government agency, to regionally decentralized corporate subsidiaries under a holding company structure. (b) EGAT has been classified as an "Excellent State Enterprise". PEA is to achieve this status by mid-1996. The excellent state enterprise status requires: (i) return on assets employed greater than 6%; (ii) labor cost below 10% of total costs; and (iii) annual productivity increases equal to or greater than 2%. Achievement of the excellent state enterprise status provides management with the authority to devise and implement a suitable staffing and compensation system. This step has had a major impact in improving management incentives and is crucial to achieving a smooth transition to a commercial operating status. (c) EGAT's fuel purchases from PTT are now made on a sound commercial basis. In the past, EGAT has been obliged to purchase all of its oil from PTT. Under the Government's privatization program, EGAT was allowed in 1993 to purchase oil on the open market, on a trial basis. PTT won the competitive tender for the trial
 10 purchase, which was deemed a success. While the agreement for commercial heavy oil purchases from PTT has been completed, a natural gas agreement is still being negotiated and would be completed in 1996. (d) Plans for organizational restructuring of EGAT have been approved. These plans while were effective by April- 1996 envisage the creation of six business units (i.e. profit centers), and five operating units (i.e. cost centers). The business units are: thermal generation; transmission; engineering; construction; mining and maintenance. The operating units are: governors office and internal audit; hydro power plants; administration; accounting and finance; policy and planning and new business ventures. Asset restructuring for the creation of profit centers is in progress. The business units will be corporatized in line with the broad sector restructuring strategy of the Government. All transactions between business units will be conducted on the basis of transparent transfer prices. Once this structure is developed on a sound commercial footing, the business units will be either wholly or partially privatized. The progress on privatization will depend on the absorptive capacity of domestic capital markets. Power Sector Restructuring (a) In February 1996, the National Energy Policy Office (NEPO) submitted and obtained approval by the Cabinet for a medium-term structure for the Electricity Supply Industry. This structure shown in Annex 6 envisages the formation of a central purchasing agency comprising the existing EGAT transmission system and hydro power plants. This entity will be an independent corporation. The thermal plants under EGAT will be corporatized as an independent generation subsidiary. All transactions between the central purchasing agency and power suppliers will be based on fully-dispatchable power purchase agreements (PPAs) in order to ensure productive efficiency in the power system. (b) The uniform tariff policy has required that retail sales of MEA and PEA be priced uniformly throughout the country. EGAT's differential tariffs to MEA and PEA have been the vehicle of subsidization from the urban to the rural areas. It has been the Government's intention to eliminate the cross subsidy scheme from EGAT's tariffs before its privatization. A Study on the Rationalization of Bulk Supply Tariff to MEA and PEA is being undertaken with Bank financing under the Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project (Loan 3884-TH). The study would provide a model bulk power agreement with MEA and PEA, the first step in formalizing MEA and PEA contracts that would eliminate cross subsidies. NEPO expects the revised bulk tariff structure to be introduced in 1996.

BANK LENDING FOR THE SECTOR Experience with Past Loans 1.24 The Bank has made 24 loans to Thailand for power, of which five have been made to PEA (three for rural electrification and two for distribution reinforcement), one has been made to MEA for improvement of its distribution system, and 18 have been made to EGAT and its predecessor for financing the expansion of electricity generation and transmission facilities. Three of the loans to PEA have been fully disbursed; while the rest are under supervision: (a) the Distribution System Upgrading Project (Loan 3404- TH) disbursed more slowly than expected at the initial phase of the project because of a change in consultants and delays in land procurement for substations; and (b) the Distribution System Reinforcement Project (Loan 3798-TH) has been delayed by about a year in its implementation because of initial delays in finalizing consultancy contracts and problems with design and procurement of transmission lines. The overall progress in the implementation of MEA's Distribution System and Energy Efficiency Project (Loan 3598-TH) is satisfactory and about half of the work is now completed. Of the 18 loans to EGAT, 17 have been fully disbursed and the only on-going project is the Lam Takhong Pump Storage Project (Loan 3884-TH) which was approved by the Bank's Board on May 9, 1995 and signed on September 8, 1995. 1.25 PEA has completed three Bank-financed projects for rural electrification: the Accelerated Rural Electrification Project (Loan 1527-TH, completed in 1983), the Second Accelerated Rural Electrification Project (Loan 1871-TH, completed in 1987), and the Provincial Power Distribution Project (Loan 2312-TH, completed in 1989). The corresponding Project Completion Reports (PPAR #6269 dated June 13, 1986, PPAR #7756 dated April 1, 1989, and PPAR #9016 dated September 14, 1990) show that the project objectives were largely accomplished. The design and procurement delays being experienced in the two ongoing projects with PEA (Distribution System Upgrading and Distribution System Reinforcement) have emphasized the need to procure land well in advance of design and procurement activities. There is also a need for appointing consultants early in the project cycle. PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND DESCRIPTION 3.1 The main objectives of the proposed project are to: (a) improve through automation the efficiency and reliability of PEA's distribution network and strengthen its operational capabilities; (b) upgrade the distribution system in the south of Thailand to meet demand growth efficiently and at least cost; (c) strengthen PEA's engineering and management capabilities through the integration of its Geographical Information System (GIS) with the proposed Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system; (d) help rationalize PEA system's interfacing arrangements with EGAT, an important step towards its regionalization and subsequent privatization; and (e) help investigate the issues and options for the regulatory framework for the energy sector. The achievement of project objectives would be monitored through specific performance indicators (para. 3.12 and Annex 12). The components of the proposed project are: (a) Distribution Automation System comprising: (i) six control centers with SCADA facilities in PEA Central Region Areas 1, 2 and 3, Southern Region Area 1, Northern Region Area 3, and consolidation reporting facilities in PEA's Head Office; (ii) about 2,100 remote-controlled distribution line switching equipment; (iii) some 1,500 fault indicators, 150 remote terminal units and 75 Ultra High Frequency (UHF) communications links; and (iv) construction of six control centers and modification of about 150 existing substations; (b) Upgrading Distribution in South Thailand comprising: construction of about 680 km of 115 kV transmission lines and about 20 associated 1 15/22/33 kV substations (total capacity about 1,350 MVA); (c) Consulting Services for: (i) detailed design and project management of the Distribution Automation System including training of PEA technical staff; and (ii) detailed design and project management of Upgrading Distribution in South Thailand; and (d) Technical Assistance for: (i) rationalization of PEA's interfacing arrangements with EGAT; and (ii) study of issues and options for the regulatory framework for the energy sector. Distribution Automation System 3.2 Thailand's Seventh National Economic and Social Development Plan (NESDP) recognizes: (a) power system efficiency improvement; and (b) strengthening system operational and service capability as two important factors that would contribute to the achievement of a reliable electricity supply, vital for a sustained high economic growth

The overall distribution automation project involves the establishment of Distribution Dispatching Centers (DDC) in each of PEA's 12 administrative areas and a System Management Center (SMC) at PEA's head office in Bangkok. Its first phase, which constitutes the proposed project, covers 28 of Thailand's fastest growing provinces, and involves construction of DDC's for the Central Region Areas 1,2, 3, the Southern Region Area 1 and the Northern Region Area 3. The bulk supply tariff is on the basis of long-run marginal cost pricing but takes into account equity, social and development considerations as well as the financial needs of the three utilities, EGAT, PEA and MEA. The tariff to PEA and MEA as currently applied, comprises a flat energy charge. There is no demand charge or charge for variation depending on time of use, and consequently, the tariff does not reflect the costs of supply and is inadequate to give correct signals to PEA and MEA to improve their load factor, load shape and power factor or foster conservation. The current tariff for bulk supply for MEA is Baht 1.47/kwh, whereas the tariff for PEA is Baht 0.96/kwh, although the actual cost of supply to PEA is greater than the cost of supply to MEA. The difference in the tariff to the two utilities

With effect from December 1992, the Government put in place an automatic adjustment clause, by means of which the retail tariff is adjusted monthly as EGAT's costs change for fuel, taxes, foreign exchange and demand side management. The electricity tariffs are set by a tariff setting committee composed of EGAT, PEA, MEA, MOF, NEPO and NIDA. The committee meets monthly to determine the automatic adjustment factor, reviews the relative rates periodically to ensure that they accomplish the required cross-funding among the utilities, and prepares recommendations to the NEPC on the proposed tariff increases during the tariff setting period every three years. Distribution automation would bring in its wake numerous benefits to PEA's operations; the principal quantifiable benefits would stem from improvement in operational flexibility and significant reduction in unsupplied energy which would translate into substantial economic benefits, especially to industrial and commercial consumers.  -49- Annex 5 Page I of 4 THAILAND Distribution Automation and Reliability Improvement Project Regulatory Framework for the Energy Sector (With Emphasis on the Power Sector) Terms of Reference Background The key governmental organization responsible for energy affairs in Thailand is the National Energy Policy Council (NEPC). The NEPC is chaired by the Prime Minister, and its members include the National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB) and the Secretary General of the National Energy Policy Office (NEPO). On behalf of the Cabinet, the NEPC approves policies, plans, and projects in the energy sector. The NEPO, as the secretariat of NEPC, is the effective link between the NEPC and Thailand's state-owned energy enterprises. The functions and responsibilities of the NEPO are, among others, to: (a) formulate and disseminate NEPC directives; (b) formulate the broad commercial and operational responsibilities of the state- owned energy enterprises; and (c) establish policy for the energy sector. The NEPO therefore functions in many ways as a "regulator" for the state-owned energy sector. Currently, Thailand does not have an independent regulatory body for the energy sector. The regulatory role is, as described above, performed by NEPO. These arrangements have thus far been satisfactory for the electric sector because it is state-owned. There is no compelling reason to change these arrangements so long as the electric sector, and particularly the transmission and distribution functions, remain state-owned. However, with (a) the strong emphasis placed by the Government on mobilizing private capital to finance the massive investments in the electric sector, and (b) the Government's plans to restructure the electric sector and its functional units, and then move the units toward corporatization and eventual privatization, the time is opportune to investigate the need for change and to review options for a regulatory system capable of managing the requirements for transparent electric sector regulation in the future. Objectives The technical assistance study will assist the Thai Government in developing a legal and regulatory framework for the energy sector. The key objectives of the regulatory system wpuld be the introduction of market based mechanisms, fair competition and economic efficiency. The existence of a suitable legal and regulatory system, including creation of appropriate institutions, is seen as a prerequisite for a commercially-oriented electric system, especially when private enterprises begin to play significant roles. The most important of these roles are the functions that require the greatest measure of transparency and predictability, namely, the granting of licenses and the setting of tariffs. There are a number of different legal and regulatory frameworks in existence in the world today; no one model or system is appropriate for every country or system, but whatever system is adopted must reflect the cultural, historical, and political realities of Thailand. It is therefore critical that all the work undertaken be consistent with the current situation, and with the Government's proposals to restructure the energy sector. The main elements of this work, to be undertaken by the Government with the assistance of the Consultant, are to: 1. define the appropriate regulatory functions to be undertaken by the independent regulatory agency; 2. delineate and separate the oversight responsibilities of the independent regulatory agency from that of government agencies and ministries; 3. devise suitable institutional forms for the conduct of these functions, as well as establish regulatory procedures and mechanisms; and 4. develop a suitable time frame and sequence of steps through which the current regulatory system could evolve into the desired model of regulation.

Preliminary studies were undertaken in 1994, with the feasibility study submitted in February 1995. This restructuring strategy was reviewed and approved by the Board of Governors of PEA, who requested additional details on implementation. The phased approach to the restructuring of PEA is seen as a three-step process spread over a 4-5 year timeframe. Achievement of the excellent state enterprise status provides management with the authority to devise and implement a suitable staffing and compensation system. This step will have a major impact in improving management incentives and is critical to many of the changes planned in Phase 1. The excellent state enterprise status requires: (a) return on revalued assets greater than 6%; (b) labor cost below 10% of total costs; and (c) annual productivity increases equal or greater than 2%. Demand for electricity in Thailand is forecast to grow at a rate of almost 10% p.a. over 1995 - 2000. The largest and fastest growing share of retail sales (accounting for 55% of EGAT's generation, up from 24% five years ago) is occurring in PEA's distribution franchise areas. In these areas retail sales grew at an average of over 15% per year over the last 10 years. Over the next decade, PEA will have to mature from a utility, largely preoccupied with the Government's Rural Electrification (RE) program, to become a more commercial organization faced with improving the quality of service to its major industrial and commercial customers. PEA's distribution system in Thailand is extensive. It includes 194,375 ckm of medium voltage and 769 ckm of high voltage distribution lines and 28,126 MVA of transformer capacity. The bulk of PEA medium voltage (MV) distribution is carried out at 22kV and 33kV, with 22kV constituting almost 83% and 33kV almost 17% of the total network. 2. Faced with the challenge, PEA is investing about US$2 billion for the 1993-1997 period in extending the provincial 115kV subtransmission, and reinforcing the MV distribution systems to improve overall system efficiency, maintain MV system losses at optimum levels, and importantly enhance the quality of supply. The investment program will also substantially complete the rural electrification in the country, so that by the end of the century, virtually all villages in Thailand will have access to electricity. A notable feature of PEA's plan is that in building 65 new 115 kV substations (in comparison to 16 being build by EGAT in the same period), there will be a shift in responsibility from EGAT to PEA for the future development of the 115 kV sub-transmission system. 3. Continuing 115kV expansion will be needed to reinforce, at least cost, the capacity of PEA's MV networks to reduce losses, and improve the quality and reliability of power supplies to its consumers. Likewise EGAT's transmission system will also be expanding, necessitating the construction of new high capacity EHV (220/5OOkV) transmission circuits to provide the transmission infrastructure for stability and reliability of its bulk supplies to PEA. Many of EGAT's new EHV lines interconnect main power stations, and bulk supply substations, will be adjacent to the older 115kV circuits. These will become increasingly redundant to EGAT's needs, and will increasingly be turned over to radial operation more suited to PEA's needs. While some of these 115 kV lines may be retained by EGAT, where they are critical to its operations, or where they can be uprated in future, most other lines should be transferred to PEA in the interest of overall efficiency in transmission and subtransmission operations.

The TA would assist the Government to prepare the proposed project by financing the investigation of the technical, economic and ownership aspects of transmission and subtransmission development in Thailand, to assist in rationalizing interface arrangements between EGAT and PEA and thereby determine the appropriate costs of supply for charging purposes. The study should consider a number of technical issues in arriving at its conclusions, which will be used as a basis for negotiations with regard the transfer of existing 115kV transmission assets. The study will be done utilizing PEA's GIS facilities to map the structure of the existing and planned 115kV subtransmission systems, and hence determine costs of supply to PEA rural, urban and industrial service areas. The approach to be followed, and incorporated in the consultants TOR, should be generally as detailed below: (a) Digitize all of PEA's MV service areas based on the extent of supplies from 115/22kV substations. Using existing and forecast demand characteristics for each service area, estimate: (i) load densities (kW/sqkm); (ii) service characteristics (MVA fault level/reliability index); and (iii) costs of supply from the main EGAT 220/500kV supply point to the respective load center in S/kW/km. Costs of supply will be assessed using standard unit costs for different types (pole, single, double circuit, etc.) of 115kV lines, substations (dependent on fault level, redundancy capacity, outgoing feeders, etc.), and 22kV bulk feeders taken from the 115/22kV substations up to the demand center (from which the 22kV distribution lines emanate); and including the EGAT capacity charges for each of the existing bulk power substations; (b) Review the basis for establishing new 115kV supply points in terms of EGAT technical requirements (fault levels, reliability, cost of land, ROW, etc.) and determine how costs are allocated to PEA and EGAT respectively in selecting locations for new substations; (c) Review the range of costs of supply computed, and group them according to the characteristics of each service area (e.g. region, rural flat, rural mountainous, urban low density, urban high density, industrial estate, etc.) to identify anomalies in the cost of supplies and the reasons for any significant differences; (d) Examine alternative methods for reducing per unit supply costs by extending PEA subtransmission and/or reinforcing distribution lines, assuming new points of supply can be made available from the nearest EGAT transmission lines, and estimate the costs of doing so using standard rates for the extensions involved;

There are a number of elements which will make up this reduction, as follows: (a) swift notification of the occurrence of a fault; (b) rapid identification of the approximate location of the fault; (c) immediate switching to restore supply to customers fed from healthy sections of network; and (d) dispatch of crews directly to the fault area. Other benefits include improved service to customers, improved cash flows, societal economic benefits, higher customer confidence in PEA, etc. Improved Information for Planning The proposed system will provide much-improved information for planning purposes. The historical archive feature will allow feeder and substation load profiles to be examined in detail and will eliminate the need to make assumptions about daily load profiles, the variation of load throughout the year, load factors, etc. Deferral/Optimization of Capital Better information for planning will lead to more efficient use Expenditure of capital: it will be possible to defer some projects based on improved information regarding actual loads, load profile and likelihood of coincident occurrence of relevant factors. Reduced System Losses The proposed systems can be used to reduce distribution system losses in several ways by allowing: (a) the optimum choice of Normally Open position; (b) the operation of certain plant in parallel (i.e. where a fast response may be required to decouple the paralleled plant in the event of a fault, etc.) This might include paralleling two transformers which have different characteristics, or closing a N.O. point on the network between two separate distribution substations; (c) the switching out of lightly loaded transformers in bulk supply substations during periods of low load; and (d) voltage control improvements, i.e. losses can be reduced if the distribution voltage is kept as close to is upper limit as possible. Reduced Manning of Substations The implementation of a SCADA system would allow demanning of substations. Supports Future Development of Full- The existence of a SCADA system will be a pre-requisite for Scale DMS the development of a full DMS system, which would be linked to the customer billing and facilities information systems.

Improved Customer Service In addition to the tangible improvement in the continuity of supply, there will be an intangible improvement in the level of customer service arising from the faster restoration of supply and from the utility's ability to inform customers of the likely delay in restoring supply. Management of Energy during Supply During power system emergencies (i.e. major storms, Shortages and Emergencies insufficient generation to meet demand, etc.) a SCADA/DMS system will allow the equitable sharing of available resources. Remote control facilities will allow load shedding to be carried out from a single location. The accurate balancing of load will allow a minimum safety margin to be used during rota load shedding/restoration by preventing large swings in demand while circuits are being switched in and out. During such periods, it would be possible to reduce system demand by reducing the distribution voltages by say 5%. System security will be improved by the ability to carry out rapid load shedding in the event of a major system disturbance, possibly preventing a complete collapse of the system. doc.repnme: Thailand - Distribution Automation and Reliability Improvement Project
doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Distribution Automation and Reliability Improvement Project for Thailand are to: (a) improve through automation the efficiency and reliability of Provincial Electricity Authority's (PEA) distribution network and strengthen its operational capabilities; (b) upgrade the distribution system in the south of Thailand to meet demand growth efficiently and at least cost; (c) strengthen PEA's engineering and management capabilities through the integration of its Geographical Information System with the proposed Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system; (d) help rationalize PEA system's interfacing arrangements with the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT), an important step towards its regionalization and subsequent privatization; and (e) help investigate the issues and options for the regulatory framework of the energy sector. The components of the project are: (a) Distribution Automation System comprising: (1) six control centers with SCADA facilities, and consolidation reporting facilities in PEA's Head Office; (2) remote-controlled distribution line switching equipment; (3) fault indicators, remote terminal units and ultra high frequency communications links; and (4) construction of six control centers and modification of existing substations; (b) upgrading distribution in South Thailand comprising the construction of transmission lines and associated substations; (c) consulting services for the detailed design and project management of the Distribution Automation System, including training of PEA technical staff, and upgrading distribution in south Thailand; and (d) technical assistance for the rationalization of PEA's interfacing arrangements with EGAT and study of issues and options for the regulatory framework of the energy sector.
